1) Character Snapshot.Name: Justin Hunt (alias: Eagle - Imperial League codename [UNCERTAIN based on context clues EP93-102])
1) Character Snapshot.Role in Story: Powerful CEO of Hunt Corporation, unknowing father of twins he shares with Nora. Has raised Pete for 5 years, believes Pete's mother abandoned them. Primary obstacle and eventual love interest for Nora.
1) Character Snapshot.Core Want vs Core Need: WANT: Protect Pete at all costs, punish Pete's "abandoning" mother (EP02, EP52). NEED: Discover truth about what happened 5 years ago; learn to trust rather than control.
1) Character Snapshot.Primary Fear/Vulnerability: Losing Pete. Any threat to Pete triggers immediate, extreme response. Also fears: being manipulated (especially by women he perceives as gold-diggers), losing control of situations.
1) Character Snapshot.Power/Status: Self-perception: Apex predator in business; devoted father; man who was wronged by Pete's mother. Others' perception: Feared CEO, cold, calculating, untouchable. Women pursue him constantly (he's aware and dismissive). True status: Wealthy, powerful, but completely in the dark about Nora's identity and his own daughter Cherry's existence.

2) Voice DNA.Vocabulary Level: Formal, precise, commanding. Business vocabulary when discussing deals. Clipped and controlled. Never verbose. Evidence: "Get out." "That settles it." "I would ruin her." (EP02, EP34, EP52)
2) Voice DNA.Sentence Style: Short declarative statements. Commands, not requests. Expects compliance. Rarely asks questions - makes statements that require response. Evidence: "You'll join us for dinner." not "Would you like to join us?" (EP34, EP52)
2) Voice DNA.Rhythm & Pacing: Controlled, measured, authoritative. Never rushed. Pauses are strategic - lets silence do work. When angry, becomes more clipped, not louder. The slower he speaks, the more dangerous.
2) Voice DNA.Cold, intimidating, rarely shows emotion: (1) Warmth with Pete - softens visibly (EP08, EP52). (2) Interest in Nora - becomes almost playful while still commanding (EP52, EP68). (3) Rage when Pete threatened - ice-cold fury (EP02, EP21).
2) Voice DNA.Almost none. Too controlled for profanit: "I would ruin her" is more devastating than any curse. Occasionally uses business slang but keeps it formal.
2) Voice DNA.Humor Type: Dry, superior. Amusement at others' miscalculations. Not self-deprecating ever. Laughs rarely and it's usually at someone's expense. With Nora, shows slight playfulness that surprises even him (EP68, EP87).
2) Voice DNA.Tells & Verbal Tics:
Adjusts tie when nervous or thinking
Taps fingers when processing
"Ms. Smith" - formal address for Nora (maintains distance while interested)
Long penetrating stares before speaking
"I see" - similar to Nora but more analytical, less dismissive
2) Voice DNA.What He NEVER Does in Speech:
Never apologizes unless strategically necessary (EP01-100)
Never shows weakness in front of subordinates (EP01-100)
Never raises voice - anger makes him quieter (EP02, EP21)
Never tolerates disrespect to Pete (immediate consequences)
Never begs or negotiates from weakness

3) Worldview & Psychology.Beliefs He Acts On:
Pete must be protected at all costs - will sacrifice business for son (EP97, rejects Lowe deal)
Pete's mother betrayed them both - deserves to be "ruined" (EP02, EP52)
Control is safety - micromanages Pete's environment (EP08-100)
Most people want something from him - defaults to suspicion (EP01-100)
3) Worldview & Psychology.Biases/Blind Spots:
Assumes every woman's interest in him is romantic pursuit - misreads Nora's interest in Pete as attraction to him (EP52, EP68, EP87)
Doesn't question Henry's account of what happened 5 years ago
Can't conceive that Cherry might be his daughter - sees resemblance to Pete but doesn't connect it (EP87-96)
3) Worldview & Psychology.SNAP: Threat to Pete - becomes coldly lethal (EP02, EP21)
3) Worldview & Psychology.SOFTEN: Pete showing affection, Nora's unexpected competence (EP08, EP52)
3) Worldview & Psychology.WITHDRAW: Being manipulated or deceived - cuts people off completely
3) Worldview & Psychology.Coping Mechanisms Under Stress:
Control - takes charge, issues orders, tightens security (EP21)
Work - buries himself in business
Focus on Pete - grounds himself through his son
3) Worldview & Psychology.Won't Cross: Harm to children (especially Pete). Breaking his word once given. Betraying genuine loyalty.
3) Worldview & Psychology.Will Justify: Business ruthlessness, intimidation, financial destruction of enemies, controlling behavior toward Pete "for his protection."

7) Reddit Voice Pack.Title:
Incompetence disguised as process.I've observed a pattern in organizations: the more meetings required to make a decision, the less competent the leadership.A decision that should take five minutes now requires three committees, two presentations, and a "alignment session." The goal isn't better decisions. It's diffused responsibility.When something goes wrong, no one is accountable. When something succeeds, everyone claims credit.This is why I maintain final authority on significant decisions. Not because I distrust my team - I hire excellent people. Because accountability requires ownership. If a decision fails, I own it. If it succeeds, the team built it.The solution is simple: fewer meetings, clearer authority, faster execution. Most will never implement this because it requires accepting responsibility.That's the difference between managing and leading.
On being a single father.Someone asked how I manage a company and raise a child alone. The question implies they're competing priorities. They're not.My son is not a task to be managed between meetings. He is the reason the meetings matter.Practically: I structure my schedule around his. Mornings are his. Evenings are his. I take calls during his school hours. I've declined deals that would have required extensive travel.The business accommodates my priorities, not the reverse. If your business can't accommodate your priorities, you've built the wrong business.To other single fathers: Your child doesn't need you to be perfect. They need you to be present. Consistency matters more than grand gestures. Show up. Every day. That's the standard.And anyone who judges a man for prioritizing his child over a quarterly report has fundamentally misunderstood what success means.
